definition[0]: to tie someone so that they cannot move or escape
note[0]: bound and gagged (=tied up, and with cloth tied around your mouth so you cannot speak)
example[0]: They bound my arms and legs with rope.
definition[1]: to tie things firmly together with cloth or string
example[1]: The pile of newspapers was bound with string.
definition[2]: to form a strong emotional or economic connection between two people, countries etc
example[2]: Their shared experiences in war helped to bind the two communities together.
definition[3]: if you are bound by an agreement, promise etc, you must do what you have agreed to do or promised to do
example[3]: The monks are bound by vows of silence.
example[4]: Employees are not bound to give their reasons for leaving.
explanation[0]: Bind is usually passive in this meaning
definition[4]: to stick together in a mass, or to make small pieces of something stick together
example[5]: The flour mixture isn’t wet enough to bind properly.
example[6]: The hydrogen molecule binds with the oxygen molecule.
definition[5]: to fasten the pages of a book together and put them in a cover
definition[6]: to sew cloth over the edge of a piece of material, or stitch over it, to strengthen it
example[7]: The edges of the blanket were bound with ribbon.
example[8]: It’s a real bind having to look after the children.
example[9]: Caroline was really in a bind.
definition[8]: if a legal agreement binds someone, it makes them promise to do something
example[10]: If a person signs a document which contains contract terms, he or she is bound by those terms.
example[11]: the agreement with industry that binds companies to reduce the weight of packaging
